title: TLPortfolio
text:
Over the two semesters, I planned two modules. The first one was an exercise in setting up a course description, learning outcomes, aligned assessment and a pathway to mastery map.
For the second module, I made a lesson plan that I taught in one of the graduate school first year bioinformatics courses.

title: TLPortfolio
text:
Over the two semesters, I planned two modules. The first one was an exercise in setting up a course description, learning outcomes, aligned assessment and a pathway to mastery map.
For the second module, I made a lesson plan that I taught in one of the graduate school first year bioinformatics courses.

title: TLPortfolio
text:
I believe education’s goal is to create problem solvers. Through education, we learn about the facts and ideas in our fields so that we can apply them in the world to solve problems we care about. It is important to check that students can apply what is taught in practical situations where they can see for themselves the applicability of their learning. Usually this happens when people move out of their structured learning environments to environments where they have to apply their knowledge and skills to use. I think there can be a way to bridge these situations so students can both learn and apply, having both processes complement each other.
With this goal in mind, I plan to use simulation to help students learn scientific problem solving in their fields. Not only does this help them practice and enhance their problem solving skills, it also helps them make their learning their own as they recognize what they need to learn to better solve problems. Learning framed this way is the acquisition of new knowledge and ideas that changes not only the way we think about the world, but also the way we go about our work in it. The field of scientific computing is particularly suited to using simulation as a means of learning because practicing and trying different problem solving approaches is the primary way to learn.
Simulation-based learning allows students to chart their own learning and problem solving goals in class. This has the added benefit of helping them become the ‘experts’ in their ‘field’ which I find increases their confidence and engagement. In my experience solving problems with contexts bigger than just my classes and tests, helped me see that my skills were valuable and applicable beyond my classes. Looking at learning this way improved my motivation to continue learning and I hope to do the same with my students.
Further, using simulation as a teaching method also adds opportunities to teach and practice teamwork since most real-world jobs involve working as a team. Teams can be better for both better problem solving and inclusivity since students from different backgrounds and experiences can better their team with their particular skills and knowledge. These learning experiences can help students appreciate the variety of their own and others’ skills and experiences. There is also the added benefit of providing students with experiences that would normally only be part of an internship or job. From my experience as an international student in the US, I know that finding such opportunities can be quite difficult and depend on the law and school administrative policy. If these simulation’s equip students with skills they can take to a job, it could be argued that their lack of internship experience during their education is not a point against them. Since computing projects do not generally require specialized equipment, projects done in class and as part of summative assessments can be added to student portfolios as examples of their skills and expertise.
Student learning can be assessed by checking to make sure that understanding has actually transferred the way the teacher intended using exercises that test that understanding. My science education teacher tested my class every week, reinforcing our learning so frequently that I did not have to study for the final exam. Testing early and often is a strategy that reinforce what students learn in class by continuously stimulating recall. It can also help both the teacher and students catch poorly understood concepts early, before they build up and hinder learning throughout the course. Some students finds testing a particularly stressful experience. Even though they do well in class and are fulfilling learning goals, they do poorly in tests. Getting these students comfortable and confident in their knowledge of the field will help them problem solve more easily since the relevant background knowledge is well understood.
Their problem solving can be assessed by examining the problem they chose and whether they solved it. This can involve self and peer review since I think it is important for their assess their own abilities and practice looking at their own work to make it better as well as to see how much they’ve learned and applied knowledge and skills. Peer review provides practice in giving and receiving peer feedback respectfully and clearly.
Through my teaching I want to show students that they can harness the full power available to them in computing for the research want to do and the problems they want to solve. They are not restricted to the methods and solutions that others have created for them - they can make their own to solve their own unique problems.

title: TLPortfolio
text:
Feb 13, 2023


This is the type of class I can see myself teaching and it was helpful to think about teaching others what I taught myself in a less structured way
In this class, students will be introduced to rmarkdown. You will also learn about the final project requirements and its submission format as an rmarkdown report. The class will introduce markdown and its syntax, how rmarkdown extends on markdown, and how to write an rmarkdown documents that can generate PDF, HTML, and Word reports according to your requirements. We will learn how to include reproducible code, analysis and results.



After this lesson, you will be able to

Create a new Rmarkdown file in RStudio and knit it to PDF, HTML, and Word documents.
Use R and bash code chunks to run statistical analyses and generate plots
Configure how code chunks and plots are knit to the final output document.




All resources for the lesson are on the class Github repository:
https://github.com/Bioinformatics-Training-VAI/2023-data-sci-bioinfo/tree/rmarkdown/session5_rmarkdown Only accessible for students in the class
There is a example.rmd which students will download for the practice parts of class.




I overestimated some of the timings in the plan and the class finished much earlier than thought it would. However, this meant students had time to work on the homework and ask for help and troubleshooting while I was with them.





Component


Time (m)


Description


Resources






Pre-class instructor tasks


20


Check with instructors on presenting the final project requirements






Pre-class requirements


10


Verify students have R, knitr, rmarkdown


example.rmd on github




40


Background reading




Introduction: problem


15


Final project requirements: Dataset identification, report


Course director / Github




Lecture: Introduction to markdown


10


What is markdown and why use it? How can it help with student projects? 






Recall and assessment/demo. Builds on git module


5


Have them run git diff on word docs to show why markdown is better for version control





Practice


15


Have them open a sample and knit it, fixing any errors in pairs


example.rmd on github




Lecture


10


Knitting to different output formats






Practice and demo themes


20


Use the sample to knit to HTML, word, and pdf with different options


example.rmd on github




Break


5








Follow-along code demo


20


Code and chunk options






Practice and formative assessment


15


Take the iris dataset, run an ANOVA, make plots with captions, verify that it knits, submit markdown on github


example.rmd on github




Demo


10


Tour of RStudio and its config options that help with writing and editing






Homework and next steps


5


If they haven’t finished the formative assessment, they can do it over the next week and submit to github






Post-class tasks: instructor


20


Check in with students who had trouble to make sure they have what they need to complete the work







I tried to use the instructors description of the final project as the problem to be solved and the what they learn about Rmarkdown in class as the solution to that problem.

This lesson is part of the Data Analysis and Bioinformatics class at VAIGS. The course goal is to introduce first-year PhD students to common bioinformatic tools and teach them how to use them during in their work. Before this lesson, students would have learned how to navigate a linux filesystem and manipulate files, use git and github to share and version control files, and use R for basic data input and statistical analysis. For this lesson, students will need to remember the R code they learned in the previous two lessons. During this lesson they will learn how the analysis done with those methods can be integrated into one shareable, version controlled report that includes both their code and their analysis. Subsequent lessons will have more involved analyses that would require students to maintain reproducible reports using Rmarkdown and the course will end with them presenting their project as the output of an Rmarkdown document with properly formatted code and results.



During this lesson, the hardest thing for students to work with would be the move from writing prose in a what-you-see-is-what-you-get editor to one where they have to set formatting and layout using symbols and code. There are also a lot of configuration options that may overwhelm them. As an instructor, I would need to make sure they are all on the same page, and work with any problems that might result from differences in the laptops they have or their prior skillset. I would also have to make sure they understand the configuration options they need, but also let them know that although there are a lot of options, they don’t need to know or understand all of them in this lesson. They can be confident that what they learn here can be useful to them and help them learn more.



The course instructors introduced the final project requirements - which is the summative assessment for the class. However, they did it a little differently than I expected from my time in the class and did not go into a lot of detail on the datasets required or the final presentation format. I tried to incorporate a bit of that in my introduction.
The introduction went well, but the first practice/test of their ability to run the code did not go smoothly since there were differences in their computer hardware and R installations that gave some trouble. It was also clear that not everyone had done the pre-class assignment fully. This did not take too long since I was able to give them alternative ways to follow along in class.
During the class, some of the students showed that they had some experience with the subject and had informed questions, while others were very quiet, even when asked whether they had caught up to what I had asked them to do.
I had an hour at the end where they were working on their formative assessment. The goal was to get them to practice working with Markdown and generate a short, but full report on a small dataset. I’m glad I had the full time, since there was a wider range of skill than I expected and this allowed me to walk around the class as they worked and help as needed. There were some students who asked for help only as I came around. The slower students were able to ask for help to complete the work, while the faster ones completed the work and had time to explore other configuration options for their reports.
I think I could have broken down the material and added more to make it more granular - they did not know some things I thought they would. Some of it was outside my control and from the previous classes that I only knew the title of - I didn’t attend the class and see exactly what they learned and how proficient they got. It seemed like they learned some things, but did not have much time to practice them.

I tried to use the instructors description of the final project as the problem to be solved and the what they learn about Rmarkdown in class as the solution to that problem.

This lesson is part of the Data Analysis and Bioinformatics class at VAIGS. The course goal is to introduce first-year PhD students to common bioinformatic tools and teach them how to use them during in their work. Before this lesson, students would have learned how to navigate a linux filesystem and manipulate files, use git and github to share and version control files, and use R for basic data input and statistical analysis. For this lesson, students will need to remember the R code they learned in the previous two lessons. During this lesson they will learn how the analysis done with those methods can be integrated into one shareable, version controlled report that includes both their code and their analysis. Subsequent lessons will have more involved analyses that would require students to maintain reproducible reports using Rmarkdown and the course will end with them presenting their project as the output of an Rmarkdown document with properly formatted code and results.



During this lesson, the hardest thing for students to work with would be the move from writing prose in a what-you-see-is-what-you-get editor to one where they have to set formatting and layout using symbols and code. There are also a lot of configuration options that may overwhelm them. As an instructor, I would need to make sure they are all on the same page, and work with any problems that might result from differences in the laptops they have or their prior skillset. I would also have to make sure they understand the configuration options they need, but also let them know that although there are a lot of options, they don’t need to know or understand all of them in this lesson. They can be confident that what they learn here can be useful to them and help them learn more.



The course instructors introduced the final project requirements - which is the summative assessment for the class. However, they did it a little differently than I expected from my time in the class and did not go into a lot of detail on the datasets required or the final presentation format. I tried to incorporate a bit of that in my introduction.
The introduction went well, but the first practice/test of their ability to run the code did not go smoothly since there were differences in their computer hardware and R installations that gave some trouble. It was also clear that not everyone had done the pre-class assignment fully. This did not take too long since I was able to give them alternative ways to follow along in class.
During the class, some of the students showed that they had some experience with the subject and had informed questions, while others were very quiet, even when asked whether they had caught up to what I had asked them to do.
I had an hour at the end where they were working on their formative assessment. The goal was to get them to practice working with Markdown and generate a short, but full report on a small dataset. I’m glad I had the full time, since there was a wider range of skill than I expected and this allowed me to walk around the class as they worked and help as needed. There were some students who asked for help only as I came around. The slower students were able to ask for help to complete the work, while the faster ones completed the work and had time to explore other configuration options for their reports.
I think I could have broken down the material and added more to make it more granular - they did not know some things I thought they would. Some of it was outside my control and from the previous classes that I only knew the title of - I didn’t attend the class and see exactly what they learned and how proficient they got. It seemed like they learned some things, but did not have much time to practice them.

title: TLPortfolio
text: Modern scientific research is driven by computing power. Using this power effectively is key to driving good research and results. This course surveys the scientific computing landscape and the tools available for scientists that will help you as you solve research problems. You will learn to use basic scientific computing tools like Linux and the python programming language to solve scientific problems. We will also learn skills like filesystem organization, text manipulation, and choosing data structures and algorithms that are best suited to our research needs. You will get to Practice computing skills on data and research questions that are of interest to you – you could even bring data from other classes that you need to analyze. Instead of tests, you will learn to read documentation and effectively use the internet to find solutions to your programming problems and demonstrate your mastery of the class learning goals. After completing the course, you will have the skills to automate parts of your research workflow, increase the efficiency with which you process and analyze data, collaborate effectively on data driven projects and fix issues as they arise, and write maintainable code.This is a class I would like to teach sometime because it has both the basics and concepts that I wish I was taught since they make work easier

title: TLPortfolio
text:
Course learning objectives





No.


Key impacts


Draft Statements


CLOs






1


Regular expressions


Write regular expressions to capture strings of interest.


Create regular expressions that capture and/or replace specific patterns like filenames, data columns, and command line utility outputs using sed.




Write expressions to replace strings and patterns.




Patterns of interest should be scientifically relevant, students don’t have to be able to capture any pattern.




2


Appropriate data structures and algorithms


Write scripts to process data with Python.


Justify your data structure and algorithm choices with respect to how they are suited to your requirements and use cases and your error handling choices with respect to user experience.




User interaction


Write scripts to automate workflows and tasks.




Version control


Maintain a record of the development using Git.

title: TLPortfolio
text:
Aligned Assessment





No.


CLOs


Assessment






1


Create regular expressions that capture and/or replace specific patterns like filenames, data columns, and command line utility outputs using sed.


Given a text and patterns including filenames, data columns and command line program outputs, students will create regular expressions in sed that capture these patterns.




2


Justify your data structure and algorithm choices with respect to how they are suited to your requirements and use cases and your error handling choices with respect to user experience.


As part of their final project, students will justify their data structure and algorithm choices, with respect to how they are suited to their requirements, and error handling choices with respect to user experience.

title: TLPortfolio
text:
Pathway to mastery map
This is an attempt at showing movement between the types of learning experiences and how they relate with each other. It inadvertently shows how each can occur in the background.




%%{init: { 'logLevel': 'debug', 'theme': 'dark',
'gitGraph': {'mainBranchName': 'Connect', 'showCommitLabel': false},
'themeVariables': {
  'git0': '#0D6EFD',
  'git1': '#FFC107',
  'git2': '#FF0039',
  'git3': '#3FB618',
  'git4': '#FD7E14',
  'gitBranchLabel0': '#000000',
  'gitBranchLabel1': '#000000',
  'gitBranchLabel2': '#000000',
  'gitBranchLabel3': '#000000',
  'gitBranchLabel4': '#000000',
  'tagLabelFontSize': '18px'
}
} }%%

    gitGraph
       commit tag: "1"
       branch Acquire
       checkout Acquire
       commit tag: "2"
       branch Practice
       checkout Practice
       commit tag: "3"
       branch Feedback
       checkout Feedback
       commit tag: "4"
       checkout Acquire
       merge Feedback tag: "5"
       checkout Practice
       merge Acquire tag: "6"
       checkout Feedback
       merge Practice tag: "7"
       branch Assess
       checkout Assess
       commit tag: "8"
       checkout Acquire
       merge Assess tag: "9"
       checkout Practice
       merge Acquire tag: "10"
       checkout Assess
       merge Practice tag: "11"
       checkout Connect
       merge Assess tag: "12"
       checkout Practice
       merge Connect tag: "13"
       checkout Feedback
       merge Practice tag: "14"












1. Connect



Think and share times when you needed to pull out a portion of text of a certain pattern. Did your word processor’s find and replace help them in cases where the text was just slightly different?








2. Acquire



Regular expressions as an extension of the find and replace idea using general patterns.








3. Practice



In class group: Capture word patterns from text using regex101.com








4. Feedback



Pre-class assessment of what student know about data types








5. Acquire



Demo: Learn about the different string types in text and the symbols used to represent them generally.








6. Practice



In groups: Capture given patterns of letters and numbers from a body of text.








7. Feedback



What do you think you can effectively capture so far? Are there patterns that are difficult or frustrating to write and why?








8. Assess



Formative checkpoint: Capture patterns with letters and numbers








9. Acquire



Class demo: Combining the data type symbols with wildcards to capture repeated patterns within the main patterns.








10. Practice



Capture more complex of letters and numbers from a body of text.








11. Assess



Formative checkpoint: List the symbols and wildcards to represent text and repeats.








12. Connect



From your research (or your other professors) bring data that has patterns that need extracting. How have you/they done it?








13. Practice



Formative checkpoint: Using the data brought to class capture the patterns of interest from them.








14. Feedback



How did you find the real-world data? Do you think what you’ve learned here can be used or is the data to complex?

title: Teaching and Learning Portfolio
text:
In our first semester, I wrote a teaching statement outlining my goals for student success, teaching methods, measuring student learning, and making inclusive learning environments. I also made a video describing by thoughts on problem solving as a student learning goal and the pedagogical strategies that can be used to help students reach that goal.



Over the two semesters, I planned two modules. The first one was an exercise in setting up a course description, learning outcomes, aligned assessment and a pathway to mastery map.
For the second module, I made a lesson plan that I taught in one of the graduate school first year bioinformatics courses.

For the second module, I made a lesson plan that I taught in one of the graduate school first year bioinformatics courses.
